answers.answer: Hi.  If your mother is having a hip replacement because of a condition which is unrelated to her breast cancer (example: arthritis), she shouldn't have to worry about the possibility of the surgery triggering a cancer recurrence.If she has any other chronic illnesses - heart disease, diabetes or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease - these may pose an increased risk for the surgery.  These other illnesses can potentially delay recovery from the surgery or cause medical complications intra-operatively.

question: My mother was diagnosed with breast cancer 6 years ago and had a mascetomy. She is now 76 years old and has been doing well - no signs of the cancer. She now has been told that she needs a hip replacement. I am wondering if there are any additional risks - my sister thinks that her having the hip replacement surgery is going to trigger a reoccurence of the cancer.Would appreciate any opinions or comments.
title: Breast Cancer/Hip Replacement
